Fig. 1 Experimental setup of catalytic process combining with electric Field. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 CH4 conversion efficiency over 1% PdCe0.75Zr0.25O x catalyst under different electric current. Reaction Conditions: [CH4] = 0.2%, [O2] = 10%, N2 as balance gas; GHSV = 30,000 h−1. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Turnover frequency (TOF) and TOF yield over input power with the application of electric field (ΔTOF*), input power at the temperature of 300 °C and light-off temperature (T50) over 1% PdCe0.75Zr0.25O x catalyst under different electric current. Reaction Conditions: [CH4] = 0.2%, [O2] = 10%, N2 as balance gas; GHSV = 30,000 h−1. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 CH4 conversion results over catalysts of different (a) ratio of Ce to Zr and (b) Pd loading level with and without electric field (the input current is 3 mA). Reaction Conditions: [CH4] = 0.2%, [O2] = 10%, N2 as balance gas; GHSV = 30,000 h−1. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Turnover frequency (TOF) and TOF yield over input power with the application of electric field (ΔTOF*), input power at the temperature of 300 °C and light-off temperature (T50) over y% PdCe m Zr n O x catalyst under different electric current. Reaction Conditions: [CH4] = 0.2%, [O2] = 10%, N2 as balance gas; GHSV = 30,000 h−1. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Arrhenius plots upon the catalytic oxidation of methane over catalysts with and without the electric field (the input current of 3 mA). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 XRD results of catalysts: (a) fresh 1% PdCe0.25Zr0.75O x ; (b) fresh 1% PdCe0.5Zr0.5O x ; (c) fresh 1% PdCe0.75Zr0.25O x ; (d) treated 1% PdCe0.25Zr0.75O x ; (e) treated 1% PdCe0.5Zr0.5O x ; (f) treated 1% PdCe0.75Zr0.25O x . Fig. 7 Fig. 8 TEM and HRTEM images of different catalysts: (a) fresh 1% PdCe0.25Zr0.75O x ; (b) fresh 1% PdCe0.5Zr0.5O x ; (c) fresh 1% PdCe0.75Zr0.25O x ; (d) treated 1% PdCe0.25Zr0.75O x ; (e) treated 1% PdCe0.5Zr0.5O x ; (f) treated 1% PdCe0.75Zr0.25O x . Fig. 8 Fig. 9 XPS spectra of fresh and treated 1% PdCe m Zr n O x (termed as 1% PdCe m Zr n O x *) catalysts in electric field at 300 °C in N2 Atmosphere: (a) O (1s); (b) Pd (3d); (c) Ce (3d). Fig. 9 Fig. 10 H2-TPR spectra of 1% PdCe m Zr n O x catalysts with and without Electric Field (abbreviated as EF). Fig. 10 Fig. 11 In situ DRIFTS spectra of (a) methane adsorption, reaction conditions: [CH4] = 2000 ppm, N2 as balance gas; (b) methane oxidation, reaction conditions: [CH4] = 2000 ppm, [O2] = 10%, N2 as balance gas; (c) methane oxidation under conditions varying with time. Fig. 11 Fig. 12 Reaction pathway of CH4 oxidation on Pd-Ce-Zr catalyst: (a) Without the electric field; (b) With electric field. Electric field promoted ultra-lean methane oxidation over Pd-Ce-Zr catalysts at low temperature Ke Li a Ke Liu a Hong Ni b Bin Guan a Reggie Zhan a Zhen Huang a He Lin a ⁎ a Key Laboratory for Power Machinery and Engineering of Ministry of Education, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, PR China Key Laboratory for Power Machinery and Engineering of Ministry of Education Shanghai Jiao Tong University Shanghai 200240 PR China b Chinese Academy of Environmental Sciences, Beijing 100012, PR China Chinese Academy of Environmental Sciences Beijing 100012 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author at: Dongchuan Road No. 800, Min Hang District, Shanghai 200240, PR China. Dongchuan Road No. 800 Min Hang District Shanghai 200240 PR China Graphical abstract A novel catalytic system combining oxidation catalyst with electric field was applied for low-temperature CH4 oxidation at low CH4 concentration (0.2% CH4). Compared with conventional catalytic process, significant improvement in activity was observed over PdCeZrO x catalyst in electric field. For example, the light-off temperature (T50) of CH4 (0.2% CH4) of 1 wt % PdCe0.75Zr0.25O x catalyst was approximately 255 °C in an electric field with 3 mA electric current. The impact of electric field in CH4 oxidation over PdCeZrO x catalyst was thoroughly investigated. The XRD and XPS results revealed that electric field provided free electrons that facilitated the release of lattice oxygen in the ceria-zirconia solid solution, therefore reinforced Pd0 oxidation and the formation of palladium oxide (PdO x , x > 0) on catalyst surface. Electric field also enhanced the reducibility of the PdO x , which provided active oxygen for CH4 oxidation at low temperature. With in-situ FTIR technique, it was found that electric field greatly promotes the chemisorption and dehydrogenation of CH4, thereby accelerates the chemical reactions of the intermediate products, so as to promotes CH4 oxidation. The mechanism of catalytic oxidation of CH4 in electric field was proposed based on comprehensive investigations above. Keywords Electric field Lean methane oxidation Palladium valance DRIFT Mechanism 1 Introduction Global warming has become an environmental concern in recent decades. Coal mining is believed as one of the major sources of methane (CH4) related greenhouse gas (GHG), accounting for approximately 8% of worldwide anthropogenic CH4 emissions, which in turn comprises about 17% of all anthropogenic GHG emissions [1,2]. In China, CH4 emission from coal mining ventilation is approximately 20 billion cubic meters per year. CH4 emission in ventilation air is difficult to be utilized since its concentration of 0.1%–1% is much lower than the inflammability limit of CH4 in the air (5%–15% CH4). Low concentration CH4 treatment therefore is of great interest due to the environmental concern [1–4]. In recent years, catalytic oxidation of CH4 over Pd-based catalysts has been widely investigated [5–23]. Most studies focused on catalysts using palladium (Pd) as the main active metal, supported by heterogeneous non-noble metal oxides of alumina (Al), zirconia (Zr), ceria (Ce) and silica (Si) [5–17,20–23]. However, the Pd-based catalyst can hardly reduce light-off temperature (T50, the temperature needed to reach 50% CH4 conversion) of CH4 to below 300 °C in most studies [7–15,17]. In view of that, catalytic oxidation of ultra-lean CH4 (0.2% CH4) requires additional energy input, and high-temperature may reduce catalyst durability due to more thermal aging of the catalyst. To realize CH4 oxidation at low temperature, Catalytic systems such as non-equilibrium plasma catalysis [24–26], non-Faradaic electrochemical modification of catalytic activity (NEMCA) systems [27–29] and other electrochemical processes has been conducted to promote catalytic reaction at low temperature. High CH4 conversion is achieved at low temperature over plasma-aided catalytic reaction system, but electric power consumption is very high in the process. NEMCA process is also very promising for high activity, but high temperature is required to produce O2− mobile ions on the solid oxide surface. To solve these problems, Sekine et al. proposed a non-conventional catalytic process combining oxidation catalyst with electric field and applied this system on CH4 steam reforming, ethanol (C2H6O) degradation and reverse gas-shift reaction [30–41]. They found that electric field with relatively low voltage (around hundreds of volts) promoted hydrocarbon (HC) catalytic reactions at lower temperature. For example, temperature of CH4 steam reforming (CH4 + H2O → CO + 3H2) over Pd and Pt catalyst in electric field was reduced by over 200 °C, and the non-conventional catalytic process demonstrated lower energy consumption and no emission spectra [36], suggesting no plasma being generated. Sekine et al. attributed the improvement of catalytic performance to the synergetic effect caused by electric field [30–38,40,41]. However, the mechanism of synergetic effect remains unclear. It is well known that Ce is the key oxygen storage material due to its facile redox cycling through Ce3+/Ce4+ behaviors [12]. Oxygen species released from the reduction of Ce4+ is beneficial for the Pd oxidation [42] and thus promotes CH4 oxidation [7,17,19]. When ZrO2 and CeO2 form a single-phase solid solution, they can improve dispersion of supported metal, improve surface area, increase stability of the catalyst [12,35]. In the light of the role of Ce3+/Ce4+ redox cycling, it is feasible to improve Pd-Ce-Zr performance on CH4 oxidation by promoting Ce4+-to-Ce3+ with the application of electron induced methods into the catalytic process, such as electric field, magnetic field, ultrasonic wave, etc. The coupled method may further reduce light-off temperature of CH4. In this study, oxidation of ultra-lean CH4 (0.2% CH4) over Pd-Ce-Zr catalysts in electric field was thoroughly investigated. The potential synergetic effect of electric field was explored by tracking the catalytic reaction and the change of catalyst in electric field, with in-situ FTIR technique capable of detecting the intermediate species on the surface of catalyst exposed to electric field. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Catalysts synthesis The catalysts in this study were prepared using the self-propagating combustion synthesis (SHS) method [43,44]. The precursor mixture was prepared using an aqueous solution containing stoichiometric amount of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (AR grade), Zr(NO3)4·5H2O (AR grade) and palladium acetate (Pd(OAc)2, Aladdin, 99%) dissolved in xylene. Stoichiometric glycine (CH2NH2COOH) was then added to the precursor mixture as fuel. The mixture was stirred on a heating plate to ensure homogeneity and was then transferred into a corundum crucible, which was subsequently put in a muffle furnace maintained at 400 °C, where the solution with fuel was promptly ignited and run out in minutes. The residue of solution combustion was kept in the furnace for 4 h, and the calcination was done in static air for 4 h at 600 °C. Finally, the residue was crushed and sieved to 40–80 meshes as test samples. The catalyst samples were identified as y% PdCe m Zr n O x , here m and n represents the mole ratio of Ce and Zr, and y was based on the mass fraction of loaded palladium. 2.2 Catalyst evaluation Catalyst performance test was evaluated using a fixed-bed flow reactor, as shown in Fig. 1 . Two stainless steel electrodes were installed at each end of the catalyst bed with no gap and connected to DC power supply. The input current was adjustable and the voltage was determined by conductivity of the catalyst. The reactor was installed in a tubular furnace, whose temperature was regulated by a PID controller. The catalyst temperature was measured by a K-type thermocouple inserted into the catalyst bed to eliminate the influence heating effect of the current on temperature. About 250 mg of the catalyst sample was used in each measurement. During the catalyst performance evaluation, the feed gas consisted of 0.2% CH4, 10.0% O2, balanced with N2. Additional experiment with 5% and 10% H2O in the reactants were also performed since considerable water exists in other lean methane sources such as exhaust of CNG engines and may affect the light off of CH4 oxidation. The total gas flow rate was controlled at 150 ml/min. The product gas was continuously analyzed with a high-resolution Thermo Nicolet 6700 FTIR spectrometer, at a sampling rate of 1 Hz. The reaction rate (k), turnover frequency (TOF) and TOF yield over input power under the application of electric field (ΔTOF*) were calculated according to followingequations: (1) k = −ln([CH4]out/[CH4]in)/t (2) TOF = ([CH4]in − [CH4]out) × V/(ML/MW × D) (3) ΔTOF* = (TOF* − TOF)/P Where [CH4]in and [CH4]out are the molar concentration of CH4 in gas stream before and after the catalyst bed, t is the contact time of the reactant with the catalyst, V is the volumetric flow rate, ML is the Pd loading weight on the catalyst, MW is the molecular weight of Pd, and D is the dispersion of Pd calculated from CO chemisorption, TOF* is the TOF calculated in the condition of electric field, P is the input power. The apparent activation energy (Ea ) was calculated from the slope of the Arrhenius plot for this reaction. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were obtained at −196 °C using a Quanta chrome NOVA 2000e Automated Gas Sorption Instrument. The specific surface areas of catalysts were determined by applying the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method in the 0.05–0.3 partial pressure range. The physicochemical properties of catalysts were characterized using varies techniques. The crystalline structure of the catalysts and the extent of dispersion of the active species were examined using a computerized Rigaku D/max-2200/PC X-ray diffractometer (XRD) equipped with Ni-filtered Cu Kα (k = 0.1528) radiation. The XRD patterns were recorded in the 2θ range of 20–90°. The indications about the microscopic structures and dispersion of the elements of the catalysts were obtained by the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) performed on a JEOL JEM-2100 analytical transmission electron microscope operating at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. To identify the surface nature and concentration of the active species, the catalysts were analyzed using an X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). XPS were collected on a RBD upgraded PHI 5000C ESCA scientific electron spectrometer (Perkin-Elmer) with Mg Kα radiation (h = 1253.6 eV) as the excitation source. The binding energies of Pd 3d, Ce 3d and O1s were normalized using Cs 1s (284.8 eV). Hydrogen (H2) temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out in the fixed-bed flow reactor to evaluate the reducibility of catalysts. H2 consumption was monitored by a gas chromatograph (GC 2014) with a TCD detector. Prior to H2-TPR testing, the catalyst sample was pretreated in N2 at 400 °C for 0.5 h and then cooled down to room temperature. The pretreated sample was then heated up in the gas mixture containing 5% H2 and 95% N2, from 20 °C to 200 °C at a constant temperature increase rate of 10 °C/min. The metal dispersion of the catalyst were estimated by CO chemisorption with Micromeritics ASAP 2020. Before analysis, the catalyst were reduced in H2 at 300 °C for 60 min and then purged with He for 60 min. After cooling to room temperature, the CO pulses were injected into the surface of the catalysts. The metal dispersion was calculated on the assumption of adsorption stoichiometry of CO to Pd equaled to 1. 2.4 In-situ DRIFT The mechanism of ultra-lean CH4 (up to 0.2%) oxidation on catalyst surface was investigated with an FTIR spectrometer (Thermo Nicolet 6700). A custom-made flow cell capped by IR-transparent KBr windows was designed and constructed for in-situ experiment with or without electric field (Fig. S1, Supporting information). To apply electric field to the catalyst sample, two stainless steel bars, acting as electrodes touching each side of the catalyst wafer, connected with a DC power supply. Prior to each test, the catalyst sample was pretreated at 450 °C in pure N2 for two hours, and then cooled to desired temperature. The following two modes were performed to study the probable reaction pathway of CH4 oxidation. CH4 chemisorption: The mixture of 0.2% CH4/N2 with a total flow rate of 25 ml/min was fed to the reaction chamber at atmospheric pressure. CH4 oxidation: The mixture of 0.2% CH4/10.0% O2/N2 with a total flow rate of 25 ml/min was fed to the reaction chamber at atmospheric pressure. After each mode, the spectra of surface species was recorded in a range of 3000–1000 cm−1 at a spectra resolution of 4 cm−1. Each procedure was repeated in a temperature range of 150–450 °C with 50 °C intervals. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity for CH4 oxidation The impact of electric field on ultra-lean CH4 (up to 0.2%) oxidation over Pd-Ce-Zr was evaluated at and shown in Figs. 2–5 . The electric field obviously promoted CH4 oxidation at low temperature. The applied voltage was relative to the conductivity of catalyst support under different temperature, as shown in Table S3 in Supplementary material. The performance of 1% PdCe0.75Zr0.25O x catalyst changed with the input current. As shown in Fig. 2, the catalyst with 4 mA electric current exhibited the highest CH4 conversion efficiency within the temperature-window investigated. As shown in Fig. 3, The light-off temperature (T50) at 4 mA electric current was approximately 246 °C, roughly 75 °C lower than that of the case without electric field (the input current is 0). The TOF for CH4 conversion at 300 °C at 4 mA is as high as 0.0316 s−1, compared with TOF in the case without electric field (0.0121 s−1), indicating a nearly 3 times increase of the CH4 reaction rate in the electric field. However, the input power at 4 mA is relatively high and the top TOF yield over input power (ΔTOF*) at were achieved at 3 mA (0.0216 s−1 w−1). The activity of the catalyst at 3 mA, with the TOF value of 0.0304 s−1 and T50 of 255 °C, rank only second to that with the current of 4 mA. Thus considering practical application and economy, 3 mA is selected as the optimal value of input current for the new catalytic system and studied in the following experiment. When water is introduced in the reactants, as shown in Fig. S2 and Tables S1–S2, the activity of the catalysts declined due to the competitive adsorption of H2O that also results in the formation of less active Pd(OH)2 [45]. However, No apparent changes of input power and the ΔTOF* value were observed with the addition of H2O, indicating that the deactivation of H2O will not significantly influence the promoting effect of the electric field. The performance of catalysts with different Ce/Zr mole ratios and Pd loading levels was investigated at a fixed input current of 3 mA. Fig. 4a shows that the catalyst with the Ce/Zr ratio of 3:1 had the best performance, and T50 of 1% PdCe0.75Zr0.25 catalyst was approximately 255 °C, compared to 326 °C without the assistance of electric field. Reduction of precious metal loading level usually lowers the performance of catalyst. As shown in Fig. 4b, cutting down the Pd loading reduced CH4 oxidation rate, but the electric field could compensate for the efficiency loss due to the decrease of Pd loading. For example, the performance of 0.5% PdCe0.75Zr0.25O x with electric field was comparable to that of 1% PdCe0.75Zr0.25 in conventional catalytic reaction. As shown in Fig. 5, the TOF value over 1% PdCe0.5Zr0.5O x in the electric field is lower than 1% PdCe0.25Zr0.75, However, the T50 of 1% PdCe0.5Zr0.5O x in the electric field is much lower than 1% PdCe0.25Zr0.75 due to a good Pd dispersion with higher ratio of Ce to Zr. The input power dramatically increased with higher Zr percent in the catalyst support, resulting in rather low ΔTOF* value over both 1% PdCe0.5Zr0.5O x and 1% PdCe0.25Zr0.75O x . In addition, the Pd loading percent exert no obvious influence on the input power. The 0.5% PdCe0.75Zr0.25O x with the largest Pd dispersion have the highest TOF value (0.0296 s−1) as well as ΔTOF* value (0.0215 s−1 w−1) in the electric field. However, the T50 over 0.5% PdCe0.75Zr0.25O x in the electric field (325 °C) is approximately 70 °C higher than 1% PdCe0.75Zr0.25 due to low Pd loading in the catalyst. It can be concluded that electric field is essentially a kind of assisted catalytic technique that is dependent on the active elements in the catalyst. Fig. 6 shows the corresponding Arrhenius plots of the catalysts for the catalytic CH4 oxidation with and without the electric field. The associated activation energies (Ea ) are calculated and listed in Table 1 . The activation energies for CH4 oxidation reaction in the electric field is lowered with the application of electric field. The activation energy over 1% PdCe0.75Zr0.25O x is 55.9 kJ with the input current of 3 mA, nearly half of the activation energy of 28.1 kJ without electric field, leading to a significant decline of the light off temperature for CH4. The Arrhenius plots of the catalysts 1% PdCe0.75Zr0.25O x for catalytic CH4 oxidation under different current is shown in Fig. S2, Comparing with changing the ratio of Ce to Zr or increasing the Pd loading level in the catalyst, which will also cut down the activation energy for CH4 oxidation, as shown in Table 1, the application of electric field is a more reasonable way with remarkable effect and good economy (Table 2 ). 3.2 Structural properties of catalytic materials The XRD analysis results are presented in Fig. 7 . Fresh catalysts (Fig. 7a–c) showed intensive and sharp diffraction peaks between CeO2 and ZrO2 peaks, suggesting uniform Ce-Zr-O solid solution structure. Microcrystalline phase of Pd and PdO were not detected, indicating that both were evenly distributed on the catalyst support. The XRD results of catalysts treated in electric field at 300 °C (Fig. 7d–f) showed that the diffraction peaks were identical to those of fresh 1% PdCe0.5Zr0.5 sample, meaning catalyst structure was not changed after treated in electric field. Weak Ce2O3 peaks was detected in the XRD spectrum of the treated catalysts, indicating that CeO2 was partially reduced to Ce2O3 in electric field. It is concluded that electric field may promote CeO2 to release O atom under oxygen-free conditions, as the Eq. (4) shows. (4) C e 4 + O 2 + e − → C e 3 + O 1.5 + 0.5 O 2 − Such transformation may also happen in the sample treated in experimental atmosphere mixture with O2, but the formed Ce2O3 will be quickly oxidized to CeO2 by gaseous oxygen. It is well known that CeO2 has “oxygen storage capacity”, which is the foundation of the modern three-way catalyst (TWC) widely used in stoichiometric combustion engine emissions control of HC, CO and NO x . Since CH4 oxidation requires O2, it should be reasonably able to assume that higher CeO2 loading favors CH4 oxidation in electric field. The TEM and HRTEM of the 1% PdCe m Zr n O x are shown in Fig. 8 . The ceria based oxides observed with the interplanar spacing of about 0.312 nm correspond to CeO2 (111). The crystal size order of fresh and treated catalysts. The d-spacing values at around 0.194 nm and 0.224 nm are attributed to the (101) plane and (111) plane of Pd. PdO(101) plane are observed on ceria based oxide grains surface treated catalysts with the d-spacing value of about 0.26, indicating that the conversion of Pd to PdO was induced in the electric field. However, The average crystal size of the catalyst grow smaller after treated in the electric field, resulting from the re-dispersion of newly formed PdO clusters [46] and smaller size of CeO2 after the reduction process in the electric field shown in the Eq. (4). The crystal size order of fresh catalysts is 1% PdCe0.5Zr0.5O x < 1% PdCe0.75Zr0.25O x < 1% PdCe0.25Zr0.75O x , and the size of treated 1% PdCe0.75Zr0.25O x (11.4 nm) is nearly the same with that of 1% PdCe0.5Zr0.5O x (11.1 nm). It indicates that more Pd oxidation as well as CeO2 reduction process happens on the surface of 1% PdCe0.75Zr0.25O x in the electric field. 3.3 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) The XPS spectra of O (1s), Pd (3d) and Ce (3d) of 1% PdCe0.75Zr0.25O x , 1% PdCe0.5Zr0.5O x and 1% PdCe0.25Zr0.75O x catalysts were tested to clarify the atomic concentrations and valence states of the fresh sample and the sample treated in pure N2 at 300 °C for two hours in electric field. Oxygen with high mobility on catalyst surface has been proved to be the key species in catalytic process [47]. As can be seen in Fig. 9 a, the spectrum of the O (1s) had double asymmetric peaks, one of which is assigned to lattice oxygen (OL) with the binding energy of 528.9–529.5 eV, the other with higher binding energy (530.7–531.2 eV) corresponds to surface oxygen (OA). As presented in Table 3 , the surface oxygen ratio of the fresh 1% PdCe m Zr n O x catalyst bear on the Ce/Zr ratio, and 1% PdCe0.75Zr0.25O x had higher surface oxygen ratio than other samples. Significant increase of surface oxygen was observed in the spectrum of treated catalysts. Since the samples were treated in pure N2, the increase of surface oxygen can be attributed to the transformation of lattice oxygen, demonstrating that electric field accelerates the transition of lattice oxygen to surface oxygen. According to the M–K mechanism, CH4 oxidation mainly occurs on the site pairs consisting of PdO x and metallic Pd0 species [20], and PdO x reduction provides oxygen for CH4 oxidation, suggesting that the chemical state of Pd species in catalyst is crucial to CH4 oxidation. The most intense palladium spectrum Pd (3d5/2) presented in Fig. 9b was used to identify the chemical state of Pd species. In Fig. 9b, the characteristic peaks at the specific binding energies of 339.0, 336.5 and 335.1 eV were ascribed to Pd x + (x > 2), Pd2+ and Pd0 respectively [48]. As shown in Table 3, metal palladium (Pd0) occupied the majority on the surface of fresh sample. It is interesting that the ratios of Pd0/(Pd0 + Pd2+ + Pd4+) in treated samples were much lower than that in fresh samples, suggesting that more Pd0 in treated samples was oxidized, since electric field boosted the transition of lattice oxygen to surface oxygen. Ceria (Ce) stores and releases oxygen through the redox cycle of Ce3+ ↔ Ce4+. In the XPS spectra of Ce (3d), as shown in Fig. 9c, two broad peaks at the binding energy of 901.0 and 883.0 eV were ascribed to Ce (3d3/2) and Ce (3d5/2), composed of peaks attributed to the Ce4+ (882.0, 888.0, 898.5, 901.0, 907.0 and 916.0 eV) and Ce3+ (885.6and 903.8 eV) respectively. It is generally recognized that the occurrence of Ce3+ is associated with the formation of oxygen vacancies according to the electro neutrality principle [21]. As shown in the XPS spectra, electric field increased the fraction of Ce3+ species, therefore created more surface oxygen benefiting CH4 oxidation. 3.4 H2-temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) H2-TPR was performed to evaluate the reducibility of PdO x species, a vital factor influencing the oxidation ability of catalysts. As shown in Fig. 10 , hydrogen consumption peaks were detected and termed as α and β [9,42]. Peak α comes from the reduction of the PdO x species dispersed on the surface of support. Peak β is attributed to both the reduction of PdO x species interacting with ceria-zirconia support and the reduction of Ce4+ by the hydrogen absorbed on PdO x . The profiles of fresh PdCeZrO x catalysts exhibited single reduction peak around 90 °C (defined as peak β), indicating no high dispersed PdO x species on fresh catalyst surface. When electric field was applied, peak α was detected, suggesting that dispersed PdO x species formed on catalyst surface. The results confirmed that electric field transformed lattice oxygen to surface oxygen, oxidizing Pd0 into PdO x species on catalyst surface. The area of peak β obviously increased and the peak position shifted to lower temperature in electric field, suggesting that more PdO x species were reduced by H2, and PdO x reduction occurred at lower temperature. On the other hand, electric field can promote CeO2 reduction, as proved by the XPS result, may also contribute to the growth of peak β. 3.5 In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) The chemisorption and activation of CH4 on the catalyst were studied firstly by feeding CH4 (0.2%)/N2 gas mixture into the DRIFT in-situ cell. In the case without electric field, as shown in Fig. 11 a, the bands at 1580 cm−1 attributed to formates (HCO or HCOO) were observed below 200 °C, suggesting that the adsorbed CH4 can be partially oxidized by oxygen species on the catalyst surface at a temperature below 200 °C. The formates were then further oxidized at higher temperature. The bands of carbonate (1460 cm−1, 1370 cm−1, 1269 cm−1) [21,49] appeared above 300 °C. However, complete oxidation of CH4 was not found since no CO2 band was detected within temperature window of 100–450 °C. When electric field was applied (the input current is 3 mA), the bands of formates (1580 cm−1) [21] and carbonates were stronger, indicating more CH4 were adsorbed and partially oxidized on catalyst surface. It was interesting that the band of CO2 (2300–2400 cm−1) appeared above 400 °C, suggesting that CH4 could be completely oxidized without gas oxygen if only electric field was applied. This result agrees with the XPS analysis, which proves that electric field can promote OA/(OA + OL) ratio and Pd0 oxidation therefore benefits CH4 oxidation. In Fig. 11b, when electric field was not applied, the band of formates (1580 cm−1) was observed at 200 °C, and the wave of hydroxyl (OH, 1610 cm−1) was found above 200 °C. The bands of carbonates and CO2 appeared above 300 °C and significant CO2 band was observed at 350 °C. It was interesting that the formate band disappeared above 400 °C, suggesting that formates was highly reactive intermediate at high temperature. When electric field was applied to the catalyst wafer(the input current is 3 mA), CO2 appeared at a much lower temperature of 200 °C. The bands of carbonates were strengthened and the formates disappeared above 200 °C, indicating that electric field greatly enhanced the dehydrogenation of CH4 at low temperature, thus significantly promoted CH4 oxidation on catalyst surface. However, at the temperature of 150 °C, the chemisorption of CH4 is still very low in the electric field, which is in good agreement with the results in Section 3.1 that the conversion is almost zero in any condition with any catalysts at 150 °C. To penetrate into the mechanisms of electric field affecting on catalytic reaction, alternative experiments were done at 300 °C by switching on/off electric field and gas O2. The spectra of alternative experiments were recorded in Fig. 11c. At the first stage(AI, AII, AIII), gas O2 was added without electric field. Under this condition, formates (1580 cm−1) was detected at 1 min (AI), then bidentate carbonate species (1460 cm−1, 1360 cm−1, 1269 cm−1) was observed at AII. The band intensity of bidentate carbonate rises with the decrease of bands of formates as time goes on, then CO2 (2300–2400 cm−1) appears at AIII. At the second stage (BI, BII), electric field was switched on, and significant increment of carbonates and CO2 was observed (BI), while the intensity of formates band (1591 cm−1) and hydroxyl (1610 cm−1) declines to flat in a few minutes (BII). That confirms the results shown in Fig. 11b that no formates forms on catalyst surface above 300 °C when electric field was applied. At the third stage (CI, CII), gas O2 was cut off, the formates band reappear at first(CI), then carbonaceous species (formates, carbonate and CO2) almost drop to zero(CII), due to the depleting of active oxygen species on catalyst surface. We presume that the formation and conversion of formates are highly depended on the surface oxygen being converted from lattice oxygen in electric field. When gas O2 was switched off, regeneration of lattice oxygen was stopped, as a result, both formates formation and formates oxidation fade away due to lack of surface oxygen. When gas O2 was fed again (D), the spectrum is nearly the same with previous pattern before the cut off of gas oxygen (BII), indicating that the consumed oxygen species can be refreshed from the gas oxygen. Finally the electric field was powered off (E), the spectrum return to the original patterns (AIII), indicating that the synergetic effect of electric field in CH4 oxidation is reversible. 3.6 Discussion on the mechanisms of CH4 oxidation In conventional CH4 oxidation over Pd catalyst, the key surface reactions mainly take place around the site pairs of Pd0 − Pd x + (x > 0), and PdO x reduction provides oxygen for CH4 oxidation [20]. The completely conventional CH4 oxidation pathway at low temperature is shown in Fig. 12 a. The absorbed CH4 molecular on Pd0 sites collides with active oxygen species of PdO x and is dehydrogenated to produce methyl group and free H ions, which then form OH group on the PdO x sites (Step 1). Two OH radicals may react and produce H2O and the residual O may participate in oxidation of CH species to formates species such as CHO or HCOO (Step 2). The breakdown of the CH bond of formates gives birth to carbonates and the released free H ions will either form OH on the PdO x sites or react with OH to form H2O (Step 3). The consumed oxygen species can be refreshed from the Ce oxide in the support with reduction of Ce4+ → Ce3+, and such O transition occurs in the entire CH4 oxidation process. The formed carbonates species will be oxidized to CO2 (Step 4) and the consumed oxygen species in the catalyst will finally be complemented by gaseous oxygen (Step 5). In XPS analysis, the spectrum of the O (1s) suggested that electric field promoted the transition of lattice oxygen to surface oxygen. It was speculated that electric field provided free electrons that could facilitate the release of lattice oxygen from the ceria-zirconia solid solution (Reaction (4)), so that generated more surface oxygen of O−, O2- and O2 2− (Eqs. (5)–(7)) on catalyst surface, consequently promotes Pd0 oxidation (Eqs. (8)–(10)) and provides more Pd0-Pd x + site pairs for dehydrogenation and CH4 oxidation. (5) 2 Ce O 2 + e − → C e 2 O 3 + O − (6) O − + e − → O 2 − (7) 2 O − → O 2 2 − (8) P d 0 + O − → PdO + e − (9) P d 0 + O 2 − → PdO + 2 e − (10) P d 0 + O 2 2- → Pd O 2 + 2 e - Based on the above analysis, it can be concluded that electric field plays multiple roles in the catalytic oxidation of CH4, and the synergetic effect of electric field can essentially be attributed to promoting CH4 dehydrogenation, Pd0 oxidation and Pd x + reduction. This also explains the result that the promoting effect of electric field is independent of addition of water due to the quick regeneration of active sites in the electric field. According to the FTIR results, the oxygen species from the lattice of Ce-Zr-O support play an important role in the chemisorption of CH4 with absence of gas oxygen. However, it is hard to tell whether oxygen species from catalyst or gas promotes the activation and chemisorption of CH4 in fuel methane oxidation. The activity test and XPS results shows that the catalyst with the best catalytic performance have the highest ceria ratio and most active surface oxygen species (OA) in the electric field, which suggests that lattice oxygen mobility is an important component for CH4 oxidation. Based on the comprehensive investigations, the probable reaction mechanism of catalytic oxidation of CH4 in the electric field is proposed and shown in Fig. 12b. With the assistance of electric field, more lattice oxygen species are released through Ce4+ → Ce3+ reduction process thus generated more site pairs of Pd0 − Pd x + (x > 0) (Step 1), providing more oxygen species for the chemisorption and dehydrogenation of CH4 (Step 2). As proved by TPR experiment, electric field also promotes the reducibility of PdO x , therefore makes CH4 oxidation happen at lower temperature. With dehydrogenation process accelerated in the electric field, the break of CH bonds in CH species occurs before the formation of the CO bond; as a result, carbonates are directly created from the decomposition and oxidation of CH species rather than from the breakdown of the CH bond of formates (Step 3). This step may also occur in conventional CH4 oxidation reaction at high temperature of above 400 °C, compared with lower temperature of above 200 °C in electric field. Carbonates are then oxidized to CO2 (Step 4) and the consumed oxygen in catalyst will be replenished by gaseous oxygen (Step 5), with the same process described in Step 4 and Step 5 in Fig. 12a. As shown discussed above, reduction of CeO2 by electron is the first step in the mechanism of CH4 oxidation in the electric field and can provide O − for the subsequent reactions. Therefore, the 1% PdCe0.75Zr0.25O x catalyst with the highest Ce/Zr ratio in this study has the strongest synergetic effect, and this has been confirmed by catalyst performance testing. Higher electric current (>3 mA) may lead to more O 2- formation (Eq. (6)) and reduce the conversion yield of specific power, due to the fact that the oxidation ability of O 2 − is much lower than that of O − and O2 2−. 4 Conclusions Catalytic oxidation of ultra-lean CH4 (up to 0.2%) at low-temperature was achieved over Pd-Ce-Zr catalysts with the assistance of electric field. The light-off temperature (T50) of catalysts was substantially reduced with the presence of the electric field, which can potentially reduce Pd loading level while maintaining the same level of efficiency. With thorough investigation on catalysts characterization, it was concluded that electric field promotes CH4 oxidation in multiple pathways. Initially, electric field provides free electrons that promoted the release of the lattice oxygen in catalyst support, thereafter produces more surface adsorbed oxygen that subsequently promote Pd0 oxidation. As a result, the chemisorption and dehydrogenation of CH4 are significantly promoted and carbonates will be formed directly from CH species with no intermediates of formates. Furthermore, electric field enhances the reducibility of the PdO x species and leads toward the oxidation of CH4 at significantly lower temperature. Therefore, electric field changes the mechanisms of CH4 catalytic oxidation, and new mechanisms of CH4 oxidation over Pd-Ce-Zr catalyst couple with electric field are proposed. The next step of research will focus on the synergetic effect between the electric field and catalyst coated on honeycomb substrate made from new material with desired conductivity. In addition, other electron-induced methods, independent of the conduction characteristics of honeycomb material, such as magnetic field, ultrasonic wave, may also exhibit similar effect on the CH4 oxidation. coredata.dc:description: A novel catalytic system combining oxidation catalyst with electric field was applied for low-temperature CH4 oxidation at low CH4 concentration (0.2% CH4). Compared with conventional catalytic process, significant improvement in activity was observed over PdCeZrO x catalyst in electric field. For example, the light-off temperature (T50) of CH4 (0.2% CH4) of 1 wt % PdCe0.75Zr0.25O x catalyst was approximately 255 °C in an electric field with 3 mA electric current. The impact of electric field in CH4 oxidation over PdCeZrO x catalyst was thoroughly investigated. The XRD and XPS results revealed that electric field provided free electrons that facilitated the release of lattice oxygen in the ceria-zirconia solid solution, therefore reinforced Pd0 oxidation and the formation of palladium oxide (PdO x , x > 0) on catalyst surface. Electric field also enhanced the reducibility of the PdO x , which provided active oxygen for CH4 oxidation at low temperature. With in-situ FTIR technique, it was found that electric field greatly promotes the chemisorption and dehydrogenation of CH4, thereby accelerates the chemical reactions of the intermediate products, so as to promotes CH4 oxidation. The mechanism of catalytic oxidation of CH4 in electric field was proposed based on comprehensive investigations above.
coredata.dc:title: Electric field promoted ultra-lean methane oxidation over Pd-Ce-Zr catalysts at low temperature
